description: Old English *snyflan, also attested in the verbal noun snyflung (“mucus”) from snofl, ultimately from the root of snout.

examples: So Parson Hugh, with Groan and Snivel
He did let his snot and snivel fall in his pottage  […]

verbs.description: snivel (third-person singular simple present snivels, present participle (UK) snivelling or (US) sniveling, simple past and past participle (UK) snivelled or (US) sniveled)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To breathe heavily through the nose while it is congested with nasal mucus.
(derogatory, intransitive) To cry while sniffling; to whine or complain while crying.
(derogatory, transitive) To say (something) while sniffling or crying.
examples: I, the Socman, am shorn of my lands that you may snivel Latin and eat bread for which you never did hand’s turn.
